reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews for games I have bought, but I feel I had to in this case, just to preserve your sanity!

During the game's intro, it declares that it will cause people to 'rage again'.  I thought it was a reference to difficult games, that are great, but can be frustrating at times, such as Super Meat Boy.  This was probably the dev's intention, however, this was not why I raged!

Simply put this a 2d platformer, and it seems there are a plethora of these going around at the moment.  The genre is going through something of a revival, and there are loads of really cheap, and excellent games of this type thanks to indie developers.

So why is this game so utterly bad?

First off, there does not seem to be any controller support.  In a game of this type, that is always going to be a major issue for me.  So then I went into the options menu to try and learn the keys.  Nope, there was no way to learn the basic controls, let alone change them!  At this point I could see many red flags, before the eventual red mist.
Next, the game starts.  Graphics were poor, really basic, and uninspired.  It made some genuine 8-bit games of old look pretty!  Music was repetitive and very grating.  Yet another factor to add to the overall miserable experience of this disastrous title.

Then the ultimate kick in the balls.  The gameplay...or sheer lack of it!  Platformers of all ilk, live and die (no pun intended) due to their gameplay.  A 'hard-as-nails' game, as this pupports to be, can be excused if it has fine gameplay, and the player knows that they died due to their mistake.  It's what creates a kind of zen moment in platform games, when you zip along, with only your reflexes and guile to keep you going.  Well, with atrocious level-design. clunky movement, and glitchy enemies, there is no gameplay whatsoever.

Listen I know this game is cheap.  That does not mean you should buy it.  In fact I think the dev should pay us all for the mental anguish that this steaming pile inflicts on the gamer!

Worst game I have played for as long as I can remember.  Avoid at all costs.  Trust me!

reviewText:
YIKES!

In a perfect world, either this game wouldn't exist, or all of its reviews would be just one word: YIKES!

Super Distro isn't just a badly-designed and completely-unfun game, it's also selfish. Selfish games are the absolute worst. They demand so much of your time and energy that you'll have difficulty going back to playing good games. Let's say you sit down and force yourself to finish this game. Even though the first level heaps mounds of crap at you, you just keep going. You gain a tolerance for the ridiculous design-decisions and poor controls. A sensible person would have given up on this game after a couple of minutes, but you soldier on. You've got the eye of the tiger, there's no easy way out, and you're the best around.

So what happens when you beat the game? Don't ask me because I haven't the slightest idea. Usually I finish games before I review them, even the terrible ones. But this review isn't about me, or the game, it's about you. You've beaten Super Distro, and now you're going to play another videogame. Let's pick a random game like uh... Super Meat Boy? Alright. I've heard good things about that one.

The thing is, you've been playing Super Distro for so long, that you've lost your bearings. You'll try to play Super Meat Boy, but you can't adjust. You'll be saying things like The controls are too responsive!" and "These levels are hard but also fair. I can't handle it!" or even "Why am I playing a game that doesn't make me wish for the sweet embrace of death?!?!?" This is why I hate selfish games. They take everything away from you and give nothing in return.

Look. I'm only writing from experience. I spent a year playing Friday the 13th on the NES

reviewText:
I like a challenging game, there's no denying that, and I am certainly, certainly not the best gamer around and this is supposed to be a difficult game, but a few things could've been done a little bit better.

First things first, I'll gladly attempt to conquer this game again when this game gets a 'reboot'. And I'm saying when, because the developer has shown that he's very much in touch with the community for this game and has taken the criticism (and I hope some of the good criticism too) to heart and has promised to fix a lot of things in the next update. The one thing I'd really like to see is a controls screen/section/menu, because while spending the first few tries figuring out the controls is quite challenging and difficult, it is not the kind of difficulty I was looking for. I understand there are a lot of games out there where you don't get the controls thrown at you, but they're not my cup of tea and for a game like this, where I think the enjoyment mostly comes from getting thrown right into it, I'd like to know if I'm only ablo to jump, can I throw fireballs, etc. Especially if you're not going to make people play through a tutorial, which can be quite boring, give them the controls to read through and maybe make them editable?

I've heard some people had issues with the performance of the levels, I didn't have any real problems with that. The only thing I noticed was that it took a few seconds for some enemies to load (which was probably done to keep the performance as high as possible).

The last point I've got is a more personal one perhaps. I am and stay a lot more interested in games (even these more difficult ones) when I can complete at least one level, which acts a bit like an incentive to keep playing. Checkpoints do that too and I understand that those take away the difficulty a bit, but there's nothing worse than finally getting through a very difficult part, immediately dying due to something trivial and having to start all over again. That's great in later levels, because I know those are supposed to be more difficult, but on the first level it kinda turns me off the game. Though I guess this does keep true to the 'Taking Difficult gameplay" to a whole new level'.

All in all

reviewText:
First ImpressionSo this is basically just Megaman, as stated in the description of the game. So for that, I really want to like the game. And I AM going to finish this game, no matter what.

With that said, the game has dissapointed me so far purely because the graphics are just a mix of different art-styles and images ranging from pure (S)NES goodness in the fonts to strange smoothed pixel art and things that appear to be just images with a cheap pixelated filter applied to them. It appears that the designer is not sure which art style to follow, of the developer does not have designer-person-individual on their team.

I also have mixed feelings about the controls, it does not feel nearly as crisp as the megaman games. But I can't quite put my finger on what the problem is. It might be the response.

At this state, I'm afraid I can't recommend it. Just because it doesn't feel or look like a profesional game. Anyway, I'm going to play some more and finish the game. If I'm not back in 6 months, call the police.

Feedback
Graphics

Pick an art-style and stick with it, the game Jet Gunner does this perfectly I think. Perhaps the art-style of Mega Man X6 would be the closest match for the current theme that's going on in this game. Just make sure it's consistent with the rest of the game and preferably with the era of games it's trying to emulate.

Difficulty

It's difficult, but it's not fun. Most of the time it does not feel like you are in control, you're just jumping and hoping for the best. Whereas back in the day, or even in the more modern VVVVVV it's all about timing and maybe just a little bit of luck.

Personally I like checkpoints that are just one bit too far to reach. But when I finally get there I always get a sense of victory, and I didn't even finish the level.

Enemies should be placed on strategic points, not on annoying points. The player should be able to stop and think God

Although I haven't played it for long, I already know why I stopped playing it.

I got the game for free, and it looked not too shabby, so I installed it and hit the main menu, which was eerily silent. 'What's going on here?', I thought. Nevertheless, I started a new game and was greeted with a rather mundane story, where a kid is sick of today's games as they are too easy, and plans to make a hard one that'll make gamers 'rage.' I try to skip the cutscene, and up pops a little 'PRESS A TO SKIP' alert. It's an Xbox controller's A. Uh oh. I plug in my Xbox controller and await the inevitably bad port that follows.

I don't actually know if the game I'm playing is the game that the kid planned to make, as it just dumps me into it right after that last line, without warning. They say the first casualty of War is truth. The first casualty of SUPER DISTRO is a meaningful story. Right off the bat, I'm hit with awful, irritating 8-bit music on loop. 'Right, time to mute that.' I turn the music off completely in options, go back to the game, and the music persists. The only difference is that the game's quality has hit 240p levels.
